content.heading: A Survey of Lineage Tracing Combined with Single-Cell Omics in Biology
1 Abstract
content.content: The integration of lineage tracing with single-cell omics has transformed the study of cellular development and heterogeneity, enabling researchers to reconstruct detailed lineage trees while analyzing gene expression, epigenetic modifications, and other molecular features. This survey paper provides a comprehensive overview of the methodologies, challenges, and recent advancements in combining lineage tracing with computational and biophysical approaches. It highlights the interplay between experimental data and modeling techniques, emphasizing the role of biophysical principles and machine learning in enhancing lineage reconstruction. Key findings include the application of generative models for distribution matching, the use of attention-driven neural architectures for cell tracking, and the development of probabilistic frameworks for lineage inference. These advancements have significantly improved the accuracy and scalability of lineage analysis, particularly in complex biological systems. Overall, this survey underscores the growing synergy between experimental and computational methodologies in advancing our understanding of cellular dynamics and lineage regulation.

content.heading: 2 Introduction
content.content:
The integration of lineage tracing with single-cell omics has revolutionized our understanding of cellular development and heterogeneity. Traditional methods of studying cell fate and lineage have been limited by the inability to track individual cells over time and correlate their genetic and phenotypic states. With the advent of high-throughput single-cell sequencing and advanced imaging technologies, researchers can now reconstruct detailed lineage trees while simultaneously analyzing gene expression, epigenetic modifications, and other molecular features. This convergence of methodologies has enabled the study of complex biological processes, such as embryonic development, tissue regeneration, and cancer progression, at an unprecedented level of resolution. The ability to map the dynamic interplay between lineage and molecular states has opened new avenues for uncovering the regulatory mechanisms that govern cellular identity and function.

This survey paper focuses on the integration of lineage tracing with single-cell omics, with an emphasis on biophysical modeling, computational approaches, and deep learning techniques [1]. The goal is to provide a comprehensive overview of the methodologies, challenges, and recent advancements in this rapidly evolving field. By examining the interplay between experimental data and computational models, this paper aims to highlight how lineage tracing can be enhanced through the application of biophysical principles and machine learning algorithms [1]. The discussion spans a range of topics, including the study of cell motion and diffusion, the use of nuclease-based barcoding for lineage mapping, and the application of deep learning for cell tracking and lineage inference. This survey serves as a foundation for understanding the current state of the field and identifying future research directions.

The paper begins with an exploration of biophysical modeling of cell dynamics, focusing on the analysis of anomalous diffusion and caging behavior in embryonic tissues [2]. These phenomena provide insights into the mechanical properties of tissues and their proximity to a glass transition, which has significant implications for developmental biology [2]. The discussion then extends to the integration of computational fluid dynamics with experimental validation of microorganism motion, demonstrating how theoretical models can be refined through empirical data. The section on lineage tracing and genetic barcoding addresses the use of nuclease-based techniques for long-term lineage mapping, as well as entropy-based analysis for quantifying epigenetic regulation. These approaches provide a framework for reconstructing cellular histories and understanding the hereditary transmission of cellular states.

The paper also delves into the development of quantitative models for viscoelastic properties and cell fusion behavior, emphasizing the role of biophysical principles in understanding tissue mechanics [2]. The discussion of deep learning for lineage tracing covers the application of generative models, neural architectures, and probabilistic methods to improve the accuracy and scalability of lineage reconstruction. These techniques are particularly valuable in handling the complexity and noise inherent in single-cell data. The section on advanced cell tracking frameworks explores automated tracking strategies, self-supervised learning, and lightweight systems that enable scalable and efficient analysis of time-lapse data. These methods are essential for processing large-scale biological datasets and extracting meaningful insights from dynamic cellular processes.

This survey paper makes several contributions to the field of lineage tracing and single-cell omics [1]. It provides a systematic review of the methodologies used for lineage reconstruction, highlighting their strengths and limitations. By integrating biophysical principles with computational and machine learning approaches, the paper offers a multidisciplinary perspective on the study of cellular dynamics. The discussion of deep learning techniques and advanced tracking frameworks addresses the challenges of analyzing large-scale, high-resolution data and offers practical solutions for improving the accuracy and efficiency of lineage inference. Overall, this survey serves as a valuable resource for researchers seeking to understand the current state of the field and explore new directions for future research.

content.heading: 3.1.1 Analysis of anomalous diffusion and caging behavior in embryonic tissues
content.content:
Cell trajectories in embryonic tissues exhibit distinct patterns of motion that deviate from classical Brownian diffusion, characterized by anomalous diffusion and caging behavior. These phenomena are indicative of glassy dynamics, where the movement of cells becomes increasingly restricted due to the complex, heterogeneous environment of the tissue [2]. Anomalous diffusion is observed as a deviation from the linear scaling of mean squared displacement with time, often manifesting as subdiffusive behavior. Caging behavior, on the other hand, refers to the temporary confinement of cells within a local region, suggesting interactions with neighboring cells or structural constraints within the tissue matrix. Such behaviors are critical in understanding the mechanical and dynamic properties of developing tissues.

The presence of glassy dynamics in embryonic tissues implies that the system's relaxation timescale is influenced by its proximity to a glass transition [2]. This concept, originally derived from soft matter physics, suggests that as a system approaches a critical point, its dynamics slow down significantly. In the context of embryonic tissues, this could mean that the viscoelastic properties of the tissue are governed by the same principles that dictate the behavior of glass-forming materials [2]. By analyzing cell trajectories, researchers can infer the degree to which the tissue is approaching this critical state, providing insights into the underlying physical mechanisms that regulate tissue development and morphogenesis.

To quantify these effects, a framework is required to assess the distance of the system to a glass transition. This involves characterizing the statistical properties of cell motion, such as the distribution of waiting times and the nature of displacements. By linking these microscale observations to macroscopic viscoelastic properties, it becomes possible to predict how tissue mechanics influence developmental processes. This approach not only enhances our understanding of embryonic tissue dynamics but also opens new avenues for modeling and manipulating tissue behavior in both developmental and regenerative contexts.

content.heading: 3.1.2 Integration of computational fluid dynamics with experimental validation of microorganism motion
content.content:
The integration of computational fluid dynamics (CFD) with experimental validation of microorganism motion has emerged as a critical approach for understanding the complex interactions between microorganisms and their fluid environments. CFD models simulate the hydrodynamic forces and flow fields experienced by microorganisms, enabling the prediction of their movement patterns under various conditions. These simulations are often validated through high-resolution experimental techniques such as particle image velocimetry (PIV) and high-speed microscopy, which provide empirical data on actual microorganism trajectories and fluid dynamics. This synergy allows researchers to test hypotheses about the influence of viscosity, flow gradients, and boundary effects on microbial motility, thereby bridging the gap between theoretical predictions and real-world observations.

Experimental validation plays a pivotal role in refining CFD models by identifying discrepancies between simulated and observed behaviors. For instance, discrepancies in predicted versus measured swimming speeds or trajectory deviations can indicate the need for more accurate representations of microorganism morphology, flagellar dynamics, or fluid-structure interactions. Additionally, the incorporation of stochastic elements in CFD simulations, such as random fluctuations in receptor signaling or environmental noise, enhances the realism of the models. These refinements are essential for capturing the nuanced behaviors of microorganisms, such as chemotaxis, where small changes in fluid flow can significantly impact directional movement and navigation.

The combined use of CFD and experimental validation also facilitates the study of collective microorganism behavior, such as biofilm formation or swarming, where individual interactions with the fluid environment contribute to macroscopic patterns. By integrating these approaches, researchers can explore how microscale fluid dynamics influence large-scale biological processes. This integration not only improves the accuracy of predictive models but also provides insights into the fundamental mechanisms governing microorganism motion, paving the way for applications in biotechnology, medicine, and environmental science.

content.heading: 3.2.1 Nuclease-based barcoding for long-term cellular lineage mapping
content.content:
Nuclease-based barcoding has emerged as a powerful technique for long-term cellular lineage mapping, leveraging the precision of enzymatic DNA cleavage to generate unique genetic identifiers within cells. This approach typically involves the use of site-specific nucleases, such as CRISPR-Cas9 or TALENs, to introduce targeted mutations or insertions in a cell's genome. These modifications act as molecular barcodes, which can be inherited through cell divisions and used to trace lineage relationships over multiple generations. The ability to introduce and propagate these barcodes enables researchers to reconstruct complex cellular histories, even in heterogeneous populations, providing insights into developmental processes and clonal dynamics.

The key advantage of nuclease-based barcoding lies in its scalability and compatibility with high-throughput sequencing technologies, allowing for the simultaneous tracking of thousands of cells. By integrating barcoding with single-cell RNA sequencing, it becomes possible to correlate lineage information with gene expression profiles, offering a comprehensive view of cellular identity and fate decisions [1]. However, challenges remain in ensuring uniform barcode incorporation, minimizing off-target effects, and maintaining the stability of barcodes over extended periods. These factors influence the accuracy and resolution of lineage reconstruction, necessitating careful optimization of the barcoding strategy and experimental design.

Recent advancements have focused on improving the efficiency and specificity of nuclease-based barcoding, including the development of multiplexed systems that enable the generation of combinatorial barcodes. Such innovations enhance the resolution of lineage tracing, making it feasible to study complex biological systems such as embryonic development, tumor progression, and regenerative processes. As the technology matures, nuclease-based barcoding is expected to play an increasingly central role in elucidating the dynamic relationships between cellular lineage, gene regulation, and functional outcomes.

content.heading: 3.2.2 Quantification of epigenetic regulation through entropy-based lineage topology analysis
content.content:
The quantification of epigenetic regulation through entropy-based lineage topology analysis involves assessing the hereditary distribution of cellular states by examining the topological structure of clonal lineages. This approach leverages the Shannon entropy of lineage trees to identify statistical signatures of epigenetic changes, particularly those leading to inactivity [3]. By analyzing high-resolution lineage-tracing data, it becomes possible to distinguish between hereditary and non-hereditary lineages based on their entropy values, which reflect the complexity and predictability of cellular differentiation. This method enables the identification of specific points in the lineage where epigenetic modifications occur, offering insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying cellular memory and fate determination.

The entropy-based analysis is grounded in the concept of a 'state manifold' that captures the multi-dimensional space of cell states, including transcriptomic, proteomic, and metabolic profiles. By integrating single-cell profiling techniques with lineage tracing, the entropy of lineage topologies can be calculated to reveal how epigenetic states propagate through generations. This approach allows for the mapping of epigenetic changes upstream in the lineage, providing a detailed view of how cellular memory is encoded and transmitted. The reduction in entropy observed in hereditary lineages suggests a constrained developmental trajectory, indicative of stable epigenetic states that persist across cell divisions [3].

This methodology bridges the gap between experimental observations and theoretical models of cell fate by linking entropy measures to the dynamics of gene regulatory networks [4]. It provides a framework for quantifying the hereditary character of inactivity and other epigenetic traits, offering a novel perspective on how cellular states are maintained and altered over time [3]. By applying entropy-based lineage topology analysis, researchers can uncover the underlying principles of epigenetic regulation, paving the way for deeper insights into cellular differentiation and disease mechanisms.

content.heading: 3.3.1 Study of glassy dynamics and jamming transitions in biological tissues
content.content:
The study of glassy dynamics and jamming transitions in biological tissues has emerged as a critical area of research, offering insights into the mechanical behavior of cell assemblies [2]. In confluent tissues, where cells are densely packed and their movement is restricted, the system exhibits characteristics akin to supercooled liquids or glasses, such as slow relaxation and caging effects. These features suggest that the tissue's mechanical response is governed by the proximity to a jamming transition, a concept borrowed from soft matter physics. Understanding such dynamics is essential for elucidating how tissues maintain structural integrity and respond to external stresses, particularly during development and disease.

Jamming transitions in biological tissues are often associated with the interplay between cell motility, adhesion, and mechanical constraints. As cells attempt to rearrange within a confined space, their motion becomes increasingly hindered, leading to a transition from a fluid-like to a solid-like state. This phenomenon is closely linked to the concept of the glass transition, where the system's relaxation time diverges as it approaches a critical density. In tissues, this transition can be influenced by factors such as cell proliferation, apoptosis, and the extracellular matrix, which collectively modulate the mechanical properties of the tissue.

Recent studies have explored the connection between glassy dynamics and tissue mechanics by analyzing cell trajectories and stress distributions [2]. These investigations reveal that tissues near the jamming transition exhibit anomalous diffusion and long-lived correlations, similar to those observed in model glass-forming materials. By developing quantitative frameworks to measure the distance to the jamming point, researchers aim to predict and control tissue behavior under various physiological and pathological conditions. Such insights hold significant implications for understanding tissue morphogenesis, wound healing, and cancer progression.

content.heading: 3.3.2 Development of quantitative models for viscoelastic properties and cell fusion behavior
content.content:
The development of quantitative models for viscoelastic properties and cell fusion behavior has emerged as a critical area in the study of cellular mechanics [2]. These models aim to capture the complex interplay between the elastic and viscous responses of biological tissues, which are essential for understanding processes such as tissue development, wound healing, and cellular rearrangements [2]. By integrating principles from continuum mechanics and statistical physics, researchers have formulated frameworks that describe the time-dependent deformation of cell clusters under external forces. Such models typically incorporate parameters that reflect the intrinsic material properties of cells, including their stiffness, viscosity, and adhesion strength, which are crucial for predicting how cells respond to mechanical stimuli.

Cell fusion behavior, a key process in tissue formation and regeneration, is another focus of these quantitative models. The fusion of cells often involves the breakdown of the plasma membrane and the subsequent merging of cytoplasmic contents, which is influenced by both mechanical and biochemical factors. Recent advances have enabled the development of models that simulate the dynamics of cell-cell interactions, including the role of adhesion molecules and the mechanical forces involved in the fusion process. These models are often validated through experimental data obtained from single-cell tracking and tissue compression assays, allowing for the estimation of key parameters such as fusion rates and mechanical relaxation timescales [2].

The integration of these models with experimental data has led to significant insights into the collective behavior of cells in biological tissues. By leveraging maximum likelihood approaches, researchers can infer model parameters directly from single-cell tracking data, even in the presence of substantial noise. This capability enhances the predictive power of the models, enabling the study of macroscopic viscoelastic responses and the dynamics of cell fusion under varying conditions. Such quantitative frameworks are essential for advancing our understanding of the mechanical principles underlying tissue organization and function.

content.heading: 4.1.1 Adversarial learning for multi-marginal distribution matching
content.content:
Adversarial learning for multi-marginal distribution matching has emerged as a powerful approach to align multiple probability distributions in a principled and scalable manner. This technique leverages the adversarial framework, commonly used in generative adversarial networks (GANs), to enforce consistency between the target distributions and the learned interpolants [5]. By formulating the problem as a minimax game, adversarial learning enables the generation of intermediate distributions that accurately reflect the structure of the input data across multiple marginals. This approach is particularly advantageous in scenarios where the distributions are complex, high-dimensional, or defined over different domains, as it avoids the need for explicit parametric modeling of the joint distribution.

The application of adversarial learning to multi-marginal distribution matching involves designing a generator that produces interpolants and a discriminator that distinguishes between the true marginals and the generated ones [5]. This setup allows for the direct matching of intermediate marginals, ensuring that the resulting distributions maintain the correct end-point marginals while smoothly interpolating between them. The method is flexible and can be adapted to both discrete and continuous settings, making it suitable for a wide range of applications, including time-series data, image generation, and biological data analysis. Furthermore, the adversarial framework naturally incorporates the concept of optimal transport, enabling the learning of transport plans that minimize the cost of moving mass between distributions.

Recent advancements in adversarial learning for multi-marginal distribution matching have demonstrated its effectiveness in capturing complex dependencies and preserving structural properties of the underlying data. By integrating adversarial objectives with optimal transport principles, these methods provide a robust and computationally efficient way to align multiple distributions. This has significant implications for tasks such as lineage tracing, where the accurate modeling of distributional changes over time is critical. The ability to handle high-dimensional and heterogeneous data makes adversarial learning a promising direction for future research in distribution matching and related areas.

content.heading: 4.1.2 Generative distribution embedding for complex data structure representation
content.content:
Generative distribution embedding has emerged as a powerful technique for representing complex data structures by learning a latent space that captures the underlying statistical properties of the data. This approach leverages generative models, such as GANs and VAEs, to map data distributions into a structured latent space where distances and relationships reflect the intrinsic geometry of the original data. By explicitly modeling the distribution of data points, generative distribution embedding enables more robust and interpretable representations, particularly for high-dimensional and heterogeneous data. This is especially valuable in biological applications, where data often exhibit complex dependencies and non-linear relationships that are difficult to capture with traditional dimensionality reduction techniques.

The core idea behind generative distribution embedding involves training a model to generate samples that closely match the target distribution, while simultaneously learning a latent representation that preserves key structural properties. This is achieved through adversarial training, where a generator network learns to produce data that is indistinguishable from real samples, and a discriminator network provides feedback to refine the latent space. The resulting embedding not only captures the global structure of the data but also retains local variations, making it suitable for tasks such as clustering, classification, and lineage tracing. Moreover, the flexibility of generative models allows for the integration of domain-specific constraints, enabling the embedding to align with biological or physical principles.

Recent advancements have extended generative distribution embedding to handle multi-modal and temporally evolving data, such as cell lineage trees and dynamic gene expression profiles. These methods often incorporate conditional dependencies and time-aware architectures to model the evolution of distributions over time. By leveraging the generative capabilities of these models, researchers can simulate and analyze complex biological processes with greater accuracy. The ability to generate synthetic data that adheres to the same statistical properties as real data further enhances the utility of these embeddings in scenarios where labeled data is scarce or difficult to obtain. Overall, generative distribution embedding provides a principled and scalable framework for representing complex data structures in a wide range of scientific applications.

content.heading: 4.2.1 Transformer-based and attention-driven approaches for cell segmentation and lineage reconstruction
content.content:
Transformer-based and attention-driven approaches have emerged as powerful tools for cell segmentation and lineage reconstruction, offering significant advantages over traditional methods by capturing long-range dependencies and contextual relationships in biological data. These models leverage self-attention mechanisms to dynamically weigh the importance of different regions within a cell image, enabling more accurate and robust segmentation. By integrating attention modules, such as those found in Vision Transformers or U-Net variants with attention gates, these approaches can better handle complex cell morphologies and overlapping structures, which are common challenges in single-cell imaging. The ability to focus on relevant features while suppressing noise and irrelevant details makes attention-driven models particularly suitable for high-resolution and high-throughput cellular data.

In the context of lineage reconstruction, transformer-based architectures have been adapted to model temporal dynamics and cell relationships across multiple time points. These models can learn to associate cells across frames by encoding their gene expression profiles, morphological features, and spatial positions, thereby improving the accuracy of lineage tree inference [1]. Attention mechanisms allow the model to prioritize key events, such as cell divisions or differentiation transitions, which are critical for reconstructing accurate developmental trajectories. Furthermore, the modular nature of transformers facilitates the integration of multi-modal data, such as gene expression, imaging, and spatial information, enabling a more comprehensive understanding of cellular dynamics.

Recent advancements have also explored the use of pre-trained transformer models for cell segmentation tasks, where they are fine-tuned on domain-specific datasets to enhance performance. These models benefit from large-scale pre-training on general image data, allowing them to generalize well to diverse cellular structures. Additionally, the incorporation of spatial and temporal attention modules has enabled the modeling of both intra-cell and inter-cell interactions, which is essential for reconstructing complex lineage trees. As the field continues to evolve, the application of transformer-based methods is expected to further improve the accuracy and scalability of cell segmentation and lineage reconstruction in large-scale single-cell studies.

content.heading: 4.2.2 Twin-VAE and residual U-Net for enhanced morphological feature learning
content.content:
The section explores the integration of Twin-VAE and residual U-Net architectures to enhance morphological feature learning in the context of cell lineage tracing. Twin-VAE is designed to enrich training data by generating synthetic geometric data, where ground truth labels can be easily created without requiring realistic morphological details [6]. This approach significantly reduces the cost of auxiliary training data while maintaining the effectiveness of the model. By leveraging the twin architecture, the model can learn more robust and generalizable features, which are critical for capturing the complex morphological variations observed in cellular structures. The use of adversarial training in Twin-VAE further enhances the model's ability to distinguish between real and synthetic data, leading to improved feature representation.

Residual U-Net, on the other hand, is employed to refine and enhance the morphological features extracted from the data. Its architecture, based on the residual learning framework, allows for deeper networks while mitigating the vanishing gradient problem. This makes it particularly suitable for tasks requiring precise feature extraction and reconstruction, such as cell segmentation and lineage tracking. By combining the strengths of Twin-VAE and residual U-Net, the proposed framework achieves a more comprehensive understanding of cellular morphology, which is essential for accurate lineage inference. The residual connections in the U-Net structure help preserve spatial information, ensuring that fine-grained morphological details are retained throughout the feature learning process.

The synergy between Twin-VAE and residual U-Net results in a powerful feature learning mechanism that is both data-efficient and robust to variations in cell morphology. This combination enables the model to effectively learn from limited or noisy data, which is common in biological datasets. The enhanced morphological feature learning directly contributes to improved lineage tree reconstruction, as it allows for more accurate identification and tracking of cells over time. By integrating these two architectures, the framework demonstrates significant improvements in capturing the complex relationships between cellular morphology and lineage dynamics, making it a valuable tool in computational lineage tracing [1].

content.heading: 4.3.1 Uncertainty-aware tracking for lineage ambiguity resolution
content.content:
Uncertainty-aware tracking for lineage ambiguity resolution addresses the critical challenge of resolving conflicting or ambiguous lineage relationships in single-cell data. This approach leverages probabilistic models to account for uncertainties arising from incomplete data, segmentation errors, and noisy measurements. By maintaining a distribution over possible lineage configurations, rather than a single deterministic path, uncertainty-aware tracking provides a more robust and interpretable representation of cell lineage dynamics [1]. This is particularly important in scenarios where lineage reconstruction is hindered by limited or imperfect data, such as in cases with overlapping cell divisions or sparse labeling. The method enables the quantification of confidence in lineage assignments, which is essential for downstream analysis and biological interpretation.

The integration of uncertainty-aware tracking with existing lineage tracing frameworks enhances the reliability of inferred cell trajectories [1]. Techniques such as Bayesian inference and probabilistic graphical models are employed to propagate uncertainty through the tracking process, allowing for the identification of regions with high ambiguity. This is especially valuable in complex cell movies where segmentation errors or low-resolution imaging can lead to incorrect lineage assignments [7]. By explicitly modeling uncertainty, the approach not only improves the accuracy of lineage reconstruction but also provides insights into the reliability of individual lineage paths. This is crucial for applications where the precision of lineage information directly impacts the validity of biological conclusions.

Furthermore, uncertainty-aware tracking facilitates the incorporation of additional data sources, such as clonal information or spatial transcriptomics, into the lineage inference process [8]. This enables a more comprehensive and data-driven approach to lineage resolution, where uncertainty is treated as an inherent aspect of the reconstruction rather than a limitation. The method's ability to handle ambiguity while maintaining computational feasibility makes it a promising tool for large-scale single-cell studies. As the field of lineage tracing continues to evolve, the adoption of uncertainty-aware strategies will be essential for achieving more accurate and biologically meaningful reconstructions of cell development.

content.heading: 4.3.2 Bayesian frameworks for lineage tree ranking and clonal data integration
content.content:
Bayesian frameworks have emerged as a powerful approach for lineage tree ranking and clonal data integration, offering a principled way to incorporate uncertainty and prior knowledge into the reconstruction process. These methods leverage probabilistic models to infer the most likely lineage trees by combining observed data with prior distributions over tree structures and branch lengths. By integrating clonal information, such as that from Weinreb et al. (2020), Bayesian approaches can better resolve ambiguities in lineage reconstruction, particularly when multiple cells from the same clone are indistinguishable. This integration allows for more accurate inference of cell trajectories and helps bridge the gap between computational pseudo-lineages and actual biological processes [1].

In the context of lineage tree ranking, Bayesian methods provide a natural mechanism for evaluating and comparing different possible tree structures. By computing posterior probabilities, these frameworks can rank trees based on their likelihood given the data and prior assumptions, thereby identifying the most plausible lineage configurations. This is especially valuable in weakly supervised settings where only partial or high-level clonal information is available. The ability to propagate uncertainty through the model also enhances robustness, making these frameworks particularly suitable for noisy or incomplete datasets. Moreover, the use of Bayesian inference facilitates the incorporation of additional data sources, such as spatial transcriptomics or single-cell RNA-seq, enabling a more comprehensive understanding of cellular dynamics.

The application of Bayesian frameworks to clonal data integration presents several challenges, including the need for efficient sampling strategies and the management of complex posterior distributions. Techniques such as Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) and variational inference are commonly employed to approximate these distributions, though they come with trade-offs in terms of computational cost and accuracy. Recent advances in scalable Bayesian methods, including those leveraging optimal transport and metric learning, have shown promise in addressing these challenges. By combining these approaches with clonal data, researchers can achieve more accurate and interpretable lineage reconstructions, ultimately advancing our understanding of cellular development and heterogeneity [9].

content.heading: 5.1.1 Motion estimation-based cell tracking in crowded environments
content.content:
Motion estimation-based cell tracking has emerged as a critical approach for addressing the challenges of multi-object tracking in crowded cellular environments. This method leverages motion patterns and spatial relationships between cells across consecutive frames to establish correspondences, enabling robust tracking even when cells overlap or move rapidly [10]. Unlike traditional tracking approaches that rely on static features or heuristic rules, motion estimation techniques model the dynamic behavior of cells, allowing for more accurate and adaptive tracking in complex scenarios. These methods often employ optical flow or similar motion estimation strategies to predict cell movements and match them across frames, making them particularly suitable for analyzing dense cell cultures where conventional tracking algorithms struggle [10].

In crowded environments, motion estimation-based tracking faces unique challenges such as occlusion, high cell density, and rapid morphological changes. To address these issues, recent approaches have integrated dynamic neighborhood formation and optimal matching strategies, inspired by video compression techniques. By dividing the tracking problem into smaller subproblems and using divide-and-conquer strategies, these methods can efficiently handle large numbers of cells while maintaining tracking accuracy [11]. Additionally, motion estimation techniques often incorporate spatial cues such as proximity, movement direction, and intensity variations to improve the reliability of cell correspondence [10]. This combination of dynamic modeling and spatial reasoning enhances the ability to track individual cells even in highly congested regions, where traditional methods may fail.

The application of motion estimation-based tracking in cell cultures has shown promising results, particularly in scenarios involving cell division and movement [12]. These methods are capable of maintaining consistent tracking over time, even when cells undergo significant changes in shape or size. Furthermore, by integrating temporal regularization and contrastive learning, such approaches can learn more discriminative and stable embeddings that capture the dynamic behavior of cells [13]. This not only improves tracking performance but also enables deeper insights into cellular behavior, such as lineage tracing and spatial interaction analysis. As a result, motion estimation-based tracking is becoming an essential tool for high-throughput cell analysis in various biological and medical applications [11].

content.heading: 5.1.2 Benchmarking and performance evaluation of tracking methods in microbial imaging
content.content:
Benchmarking and performance evaluation of tracking methods in microbial imaging is a critical yet underexplored area, particularly when compared to traditional multi-object tracking (MOT) tasks [8]. Microbial cells present unique challenges due to their rapid division rates, morphological variability, and high-density clustering, which complicate the design and evaluation of tracking algorithms [11]. Unlike conventional MOT, where object appearance and motion are relatively stable, microbial tracking requires robust handling of dynamic changes, including cell death, which is often overlooked in existing benchmarks [8]. This necessitates the development of specialized metrics and datasets that capture the full spectrum of cellular behaviors, including both division and death events.

Current benchmarks, such as the Cell Tracking Challenge (CTC), primarily focus on single-channel images with limited diversity in cellular dynamics, thereby failing to address the complexity of microbial systems [12]. These datasets often lack the multi-channel, high-resolution, and long-term time-lapse data essential for capturing the full range of microbial behaviors. As a result, existing tracking algorithms, while effective in controlled environments, struggle to generalize to real-world microbial imaging scenarios [11]. This gap highlights the need for new benchmarking frameworks that incorporate multi-channel data, dynamic cellular states, and long-term tracking capabilities to better reflect the challenges of microbial imaging [8].

To address these limitations, recent efforts have focused on developing automated tracking strategies that leverage learned feature embeddings and spatial cues, combined with Kalman Filter-based interpolation to ensure continuity. These methods aim to reduce reliance on hand-crafted heuristics and improve robustness in high-density and low-frame-rate conditions. However, the lack of standardized benchmarks and comprehensive datasets continues to hinder progress. Establishing a robust evaluation framework that accounts for the unique characteristics of microbial imaging is essential for advancing automated tracking methods and enabling deeper insights into microbial dynamics [11].

content.heading: 5.2.1 Temporally regularized embeddings for cell and organelle dynamics
content.content:
Temporally regularized embeddings for cell and organelle dynamics aim to capture the evolution of cellular structures over time in a structured and interpretable manner. These embeddings are designed to ensure that the distance between representations in the embedding space changes smoothly as morphological or functional states of cells and organelles evolve. This temporal consistency is crucial for analyzing dynamic processes such as cell division, migration, and organelle movement. By leveraging contrastive learning, methods like DynaCLR encode both spatial and temporal information, allowing for the extraction of meaningful features that reflect the underlying biological dynamics. This approach enables the modeling of complex, multi-dimensional time-lapse data while maintaining robustness to variations in imaging conditions and cell types.

The integration of temporally regularized embeddings into cell and organelle tracking frameworks enhances the interpretability and utility of learned representations for downstream tasks [13]. These embeddings facilitate tasks such as classification of cell states, analysis of temporal transitions, and alignment of perturbation responses across different experimental conditions [13]. By ensuring that the embedding space reflects smooth transitions in cellular behavior, these methods support more accurate and biologically relevant interpretations of time-lapse data. Furthermore, the ability to generalize to out-of-distribution data makes these embeddings valuable for cross-platform and cross-species studies, expanding their applicability beyond the original training conditions.

The development of temporally regularized embeddings also addresses challenges in traditional tracking methods that rely on hand-crafted features or heuristic-based approaches. Instead, these embeddings are learned directly from the data, capturing the intrinsic dynamics of cellular systems. This data-driven approach reduces the need for domain-specific knowledge and allows for more scalable and automated analysis of large-scale time-lapse experiments. As a result, temporally regularized embeddings provide a powerful foundation for advancing the understanding of cellular and organelle dynamics in a wide range of biological contexts [13].

content.heading: 5.2.2 DynaCLR for multi-channel 3D time-lapse analysis
content.content:
DynaCLR is a contrastive learning framework designed to generate temporally regularized embeddings for multi-channel 3D time-lapse microscopy data, enabling robust analysis of cellular dynamics [13]. By integrating single-cell tracking with time-aware contrastive encoding, DynaCLR maps cell and organelle morphologies into an embedding space where distances reflect smooth morphological changes over time [13]. This approach is particularly effective in handling the complexity of multi-channel recordings, where different imaging channels capture distinct biological features such as organelle structures, molecular interactions, and transient events. The temporal regularization ensures that embeddings remain consistent even when cellular states undergo asynchronous or heterogeneous changes, making DynaCLR well-suited for applications requiring precise event detection, such as apoptosis or mitosis.

The framework's ability to generalize across diverse imaging systems and cell types enhances its applicability in large-scale time-lapse experiments [7]. Unlike conventional methods that rely on manual feature engineering or static image analysis, DynaCLR learns dynamic representations directly from the temporal evolution of cellular structures. This enables the disentanglement of cell states from heterogeneous populations, even when individual cells exhibit asynchronous responses to external stimuli. By capturing the temporal continuity of morphological changes, DynaCLR supports the analysis of complex biological processes, including pathogen replication, immune responses, and organelle remodeling, which are often challenging to study using static snapshots or conventional tracking techniques.

DynaCLR's lightweight and computationally efficient design makes it ideal for high-throughput applications, such as drug response quantification or long-term cellular monitoring. The method avoids the need for additional post-processing of detection embeddings, maintaining a balance between model complexity and performance. This efficiency is critical for handling large-scale datasets with multiple imaging channels and extended time-lapse sequences. By addressing the limitations of existing tracking approaches, DynaCLR provides a scalable solution for analyzing dynamic cellular behaviors in multi-dimensional microscopy data, advancing the capabilities of automated time-lapse analysis in systems biology [13].

content.heading: 5.3.1 Two-stage deep learning for robust multi-channel cell tracking
content.content:
The two-stage deep learning framework for robust multi-channel cell tracking addresses the limitations of traditional methods by integrating detection and classification in a structured pipeline [12]. This approach first identifies cells in each frame using a detection module, followed by a classification stage that distinguishes between living and dead cells based on biologically relevant features. By jointly optimizing these tasks, the model enhances tracking accuracy, particularly in scenarios with transient signals and complex morphological changes. The framework leverages multi-channel data to capture diverse cellular dynamics, enabling more reliable tracking in heterogeneous environments. This design is especially beneficial for applications where cell death and division are critical biological events, ensuring that both processes are accurately captured and analyzed.

The two-stage architecture also incorporates temporal consistency, which is essential for maintaining track continuity across frames. This is achieved through a combination of spatial and temporal modeling, where features from consecutive frames are aligned and compared to ensure stable tracking. The model's ability to handle varying imaging conditions and cell densities makes it suitable for a wide range of experimental setups. Additionally, the integration of biologically meaningful endpoints during training ensures that the model's outputs are not only accurate but also interpretable in the context of cellular behavior. This dual focus on technical performance and biological relevance enhances the framework's applicability in real-world biological studies.

Furthermore, the two-stage approach allows for efficient adaptation to different imaging modalities and experimental parameters. By decoupling detection and classification, the model can be fine-tuned independently for specific tasks, improving flexibility and scalability. This modularity is crucial for handling the diverse data encountered in multi-channel microscopy, where each channel may provide distinct but complementary information. The framework's robustness is demonstrated through its ability to maintain high tracking accuracy even in challenging conditions, such as overcrowded cell cultures or low signal-to-noise ratios. Overall, this two-stage deep learning strategy represents a significant advancement in the field of multi-channel cell tracking, offering a reliable and adaptable solution for complex biological analyses [12].

content.heading: 5.3.2 Feature embedding and spatial cue integration for scalable time-lapse analysis
content.content:
Feature embedding and spatial cue integration play a critical role in enabling scalable time-lapse analysis by providing robust representations that capture both the visual and positional characteristics of tracked objects. By leveraging detection embeddings derived directly from a cell detection network, the framework avoids the need for extensive feature engineering, maintaining computational efficiency while preserving essential information for tracking [12]. These embeddings inherently encode visual and spatial features, allowing for effective association of objects across frames, even in complex scenarios with overlapping or transient signals. This approach ensures scalability, making it well-suited for large-scale time-lapse microscopy experiments where high throughput and accuracy are required [12].

The integration of spatial cues with feature embeddings enhances the robustness of tracking by incorporating geometric and positional context into the embedding space. This is particularly important in time-lapse data, where cells undergo dynamic changes in shape, position, and interactions. By combining spatial information with learned embeddings, the framework can better handle challenges such as occlusions, cell divisions, and deformations. Furthermore, the use of temporally regularized embeddings, as demonstrated in methods like DynaCLR, enables the modeling of cell and organelle dynamics across multi-channel 3D time-lapse datasets [13]. This integration not only improves tracking accuracy but also supports downstream analyses by capturing the temporal evolution of cellular features.

Current self-supervised embedding methods often lack the capacity to effectively encode multi-channel 3D time-lapse data or incorporate prior knowledge of cell morphology into the learning process [13]. This limitation restricts their applicability in complex biological studies where precise tracking and interpretation of cellular dynamics are essential. To address this, novel approaches are being developed that explicitly consider both spatial and temporal dimensions in embedding learning. These methods aim to disambiguate the relationships between experimental perturbations and cellular responses, enabling the discovery of rare cell states and improving the overall reliability of time-lapse analysis. By focusing on scalable and efficient embedding strategies, future work can further enhance the applicability of these techniques in large-scale biological studies.

content.heading: 6 Future Directions
content.content:
Despite significant progress in the integration of lineage tracing with single-cell omics, several limitations and gaps remain in the current methodologies. One major challenge is the difficulty of accurately reconstructing lineage trees in complex, heterogeneous environments, particularly when cell movements are rapid, overlapping, or influenced by dynamic microenvironments. Current approaches often struggle with resolving lineage ambiguities, especially in densely packed tissues or high-throughput imaging scenarios, where segmentation errors and noise can lead to inaccurate or incomplete lineage reconstructions. Additionally, the integration of multi-modal data, such as epigenetic, transcriptomic, and spatial information, remains underdeveloped, limiting the ability to fully capture the interplay between lineage and molecular states. Furthermore, the computational complexity of existing models, particularly those involving deep learning and optimal transport, often restricts their scalability and applicability to large-scale datasets. These limitations highlight the need for more robust, efficient, and interpretable methods that can handle the increasing complexity of single-cell data.

To address these challenges, future research should focus on developing advanced computational frameworks that combine biophysical principles with machine learning techniques to improve lineage reconstruction accuracy. One promising direction is the integration of physics-informed neural networks, which can incorporate prior knowledge of cell mechanics and tissue dynamics to guide the learning process. These models could enhance the robustness of lineage inference by leveraging physical constraints, such as cell motility patterns and viscoelastic properties, to reduce ambiguity in lineage assignments. Another key area for advancement is the development of scalable and interpretable deep learning architectures that can efficiently process multi-modal single-cell data while maintaining computational feasibility. This includes exploring hybrid models that combine generative and discriminative approaches to better capture the complex relationships between lineage, gene expression, and cellular behavior. Additionally, the refinement of probabilistic and Bayesian methods for lineage inference will be crucial for quantifying uncertainty and improving the reliability of lineage reconstructions in noisy or incomplete datasets.

The proposed future work has the potential to significantly advance the field of lineage tracing and single-cell omics by enabling more accurate, scalable, and interpretable lineage reconstruction. Enhanced computational models that integrate biophysical and machine learning approaches could lead to a deeper understanding of cellular development, tissue homeostasis, and disease progression. By improving the accuracy of lineage inference, these methods will facilitate more precise identification of cell fate decisions, epigenetic regulation, and clonal dynamics, which are essential for uncovering the underlying mechanisms of biological processes. Furthermore, the development of efficient and interpretable frameworks will support the application of lineage tracing in clinical and translational research, enabling more personalized and mechanistic insights into cellular behavior. Overall, the proposed advancements will contribute to a more comprehensive and integrated understanding of cellular dynamics, paving the way for new discoveries in developmental biology, regenerative medicine, and disease modeling.

content.heading: 7 Conclusion
content.content:
This survey paper provides a comprehensive overview of the integration of lineage tracing with single-cell omics, emphasizing the synergy between experimental data and computational models. The main findings highlight the advancements in biophysical modeling, such as the analysis of anomalous diffusion and caging behavior in embryonic tissues, which offer insights into the mechanical properties of developing systems. The discussion on nuclease-based barcoding and entropy-based lineage topology analysis demonstrates the potential of these techniques to reconstruct cellular histories and quantify epigenetic regulation. Additionally, the application of deep learning, including generative models, neural architectures, and probabilistic methods, has significantly improved the accuracy and scalability of lineage reconstruction. The survey also explores advanced cell tracking frameworks, such as self-supervised learning and lightweight systems, which enable efficient and robust analysis of dynamic cellular processes. Collectively, these developments illustrate the transformative impact of integrating lineage tracing with single-cell omics, enabling a deeper understanding of cellular dynamics and heterogeneity.

The significance of this survey lies in its role as a foundational resource for researchers working at the intersection of biophysics, computational biology, and single-cell technologies. By systematically reviewing methodologies, challenges, and recent innovations, this paper provides a multidisciplinary perspective that bridges experimental and theoretical approaches. The integration of biophysical principles with machine learning algorithms has not only enhanced the accuracy of lineage inference but also opened new avenues for studying complex biological processes such as development, regeneration, and disease progression. Furthermore, the survey highlights the importance of addressing computational and experimental limitations, such as noise, scalability, and data integration, to advance the field. These insights are critical for guiding future research and fostering collaboration across disciplines to develop more robust and interpretable lineage tracing tools.

As the field continues to evolve, there is a growing need for standardized benchmarks, improved data integration strategies, and more interpretable models that can capture the complexity of cellular dynamics. Researchers should prioritize the development of scalable and efficient methods that can handle large-scale, multi-modal datasets while maintaining biological relevance. Additionally, the incorporation of uncertainty-aware approaches and the refinement of probabilistic frameworks will be essential for improving the reliability of lineage inference. Future efforts should also focus on expanding the applicability of these techniques to diverse biological systems, including non-model organisms and clinical samples. By addressing these challenges and opportunities, the field of lineage tracing and single-cell omics can continue to drive groundbreaking discoveries in biology and medicine.
